content: Section 211(a) of the Antitrust Criminal Penalty Enhancement and Reform Act of 2004 is amended to delay the sunset provision from 6 years to 16 years. Exceptions are made for individuals who receive a marker or enter into an antitrust leniency agreement before the sunset date. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. Section 212 of the Antitrust Criminal Penalty Enhancement and Reform Act of 2004 is amended to include the definition of a "marker" as an assurance given to a candidate for corporate leniency. The text discusses amendments to the Antitrust Criminal Penalty Enhancement and Reform Act of 2004 regarding cooperation requirements after the termination of stay or protective orders. It emphasizes the timeliness of cooperation and outlines the actions to be taken once a stay or protective order expires. The text discusses technical corrections to the Antitrust Criminal Penalty Enhancement and Reform Act of 2004, specifically regarding cooperation requirements after the expiration or termination of stay or protective orders. It emphasizes the timely provision of cooperation and outlines the necessary actions to be taken for cooperation to be deemed satisfactory. The GAO will submit a report on the effectiveness of the Antitrust Criminal Penalty Enhancement and Reform Act of 2004 to Congress within a year of the Act's enactment. The report will assess the Act's impact on criminal investigations, enforcement by the Department of Justice, and private civil actions. It will also study the addition of qui tam proceedings to the antitrust leniency program and the creation of anti-retaliatory protection for employees reporting illegal anticompetitive conduct. The amendments made by the Act will take effect before June 22, 2010. SEC. 7. BUDGETARY EFFECTS. The budgetary effects of this Act will be determined by reference to the latest statement for compliance with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010, submitted by the Chairman of the House Budget Committee before the vote on passage.
